## Graph info
::: {style="font-size: 1.25em; color: #38B44A;"}
**When would I use this graph?**
:::

<br>

```{r}
#| label: full_code_display
#| eval: true
#| echo: false
#| warning: false
#| message: false
#| out-height: '60%'
#| out-width: '60%'
#| fig-align: right
library(fivethirtyeight) 
library(ggmosaic)
library(ggplot2) 
flying <- fivethirtyeight::flying
fly_mosaic <- filter(flying, 
              !is.na(baby) & !is.na(unruly_child)) |> 
              select(baby, unruly_child)
labs_mosaic <- labs(
      title = "In general...", 
      subtitle = "...is it rude to...",
      x = "... bring a baby on a plane?",
      y = "..,knowingly bring unruly children on a plane?",
      fill = "Responses") 
ggp2_mosaic <- ggplot(data = fly_mosaic) +
  geom_mosaic(aes(x = product(unruly_child, baby), 
      fill = baby)) +
  theme_mosaic(base_size = 10)
ggp2_mosaic + 
    labs_mosaic
```

A mosaic plot is similar to a stacked bar-graph, but instead of only relying on height and color to display the relative amount for each value, mosaic plots also use width.

We can build mosaic plots using the [`ggmosaic` package.](https://haleyjeppson.github.io/ggmosaic/)

### Notes

::: {style="font-size: 0.90em; color: #1e83c8;"}
**NOTES:**
:::

::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"}
It's a good idea to read the [`ggmosaic` vignette](https://haleyjeppson.github.io/ggmosaic/articles/ggmosaic.html), particularly the section on ordering and conditioning. 

For example, if we set the `product()` variable as `unruly_child` and the conditional variable as `baby`, we see a very different display than if we follow the standard two-variable syntax:
:::

::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"}
```{r}
#| label: create_graph_cond_mosaic
#| eval: true
#| echo: true
#| warning: false
#| message: false
#| fig-height: 8
#| fig-width: 8
#| column: page-inset-right
#| layout-nrow: 1
# build conditional mosiac plot
labs_mosaic_cond <- labs(
  subtitle = "Conditional plot",
  x = "..,knowingly bring unruly children on a plane?",
  y = "... bring a baby on a plane?",
  fill = "Responses")
ggp2_mosaic_cond <- ggplot(data = fly_mosaic) +
  geom_mosaic(aes(
    x = product(unruly_child), # product variable
    fill = unruly_child,
    conds = product(baby))) + # conditional variable
  theme_ggp2g(base_size = 14)

ggp2_mosaic_cond + 
    labs_mosaic_cond

# build 2-variable mosiac plot
labs_mosaic_2var <- labs(
  subtitle = "2-Variable plot",
  x = "..,knowingly bring unruly children on a plane?",
  y = "... bring a baby on a plane?",
  fill = "Responses")
ggp2_mosaic_2var <- ggplot(data = fly_mosaic) +
  geom_mosaic(aes(
    x = product(unruly_child, baby),
    fill = unruly_child)) +
  theme_ggp2g(base_size = 14)

ggp2_mosaic_2var + 
    labs_mosaic_2var
```


```{r}
#| label: patchwork_mosaic
#| eval: false
#| echo: false
#| warning: false
#| message: false
#| fig-height: 8
#| fig-width: 8
#| column: page-inset-right
#| layout-nrow: 1
# build conditional mosiac plot
mosaic_2var <- ggp2_mosaic_2var + labs_mosaic_2var
# patch both together
patchwork::plot_spacer() + # pad the area in front of the plot 1
  mosaic_cond +
  patchwork::plot_spacer() + # pad the area in front of the plot 2
  mosaic_2var +
  patchwork::plot_layout(
    # limit to 2 rows
    nrow = 2,
    # make plots in column 2 5x the width of column 1
    widths = c(1, 5)) +
  patchwork::plot_annotation(
    # adjust title text size
    theme = theme_mosaic(base_size = 11),
    title = "In general...is it rude to...")
```
